author: l2intern2519
content:
In the rollup-centric ethereum roadmap post, in the comments Vitalik said "One major thing that I think we are already doing is to avoid (at least at first) trying to use layer 2s as an opportunity to try to “make a better VM”; instead, we should try to just keep things as close to the current EVM as possible."

Given Arbitrum's AVM, zkSync's zkEVM, and StarkNet's Cairo VM far outpacing it's EVM equivalents (Optimism, Hermez), I wonder why he said that at the time and if it still applies now. 

My guess is security reasons, but would love to hear his thoughts on that comment one year later.

author: treyzania
content: I mean I think that was trying to warn against "yeah let's just make snarks for wasm and call it a day"

author: treyzania
content: correct me if I'm wrong

author: treyzania
content: but most of those are pretty similar to the EVM

author: l2intern2519
content: its a spectrum, but i think they are significantly different.

author: l2intern2519
content: cairo keeps nothing from the evm

author: treyzania
content: that's to take advantage of some of the cool stuff you can do with starks, right?

author: treyzania
content: like nondeterministic comutation

author: l2intern2519
content: im not saying deviating from the evm is not justified

author: l2intern2519
content: compiler based approaches are definitely more practical

author: l2intern2519
content: im wondering vitaliks motivations by that statement. and whether he still stands by it one year later

author: hikariws
content:
I'm not sure what he meant by that. I guess ETH is under pressure due to its low tps and high cost, while he wanna avoid services from fleeing to other networks.

It's better for the network that L2 solutions run dApps that are developed to EVM, instead of requiring them to be developed exclusively to those solutions. This assures these dApps are also deployed on ETH L1 or at least are easily deployable.

author: l2intern2519
content: it is a bit unclear, but i do think he meant keep close to the evm, not just support solidity

author: hikariws
content: If we end up with ETH L1 becoming just a bridge to multiple L2 instances or the final storage for hugely rolled up transactions, and most dApps get into L2 and don't work on L1, ETH will lose a lot of its utility.

author: l2intern2519
content: i disagree. in the future, most of eth's utility will come from its security and decentralization; its attractiveness to be the base layer for rollups

author: hikariws
content: I mean, if many dApps run only on L2 and are incompatible with EVM, ETH loses relevance. Compared with if successiful/popular L2 solutions are EVM compatible and dApps are deployed on ETH L1 too.

author: sky.cactus
content: I disagree with this.  I think the future utility of Ethereum is almost exclusively rollup synchronization and storage.

author: hikariws
content: I disagree with that. Rollup is benefical for use cases that create lots of transactions. For use cases that generate very few transactions and over long periods, depositing and later withdrawing on a L2 instance is more expensive and will be avoided.

author: sky.cactus
content: Those should just live permanently on a rollup.

author: sky.cactus
content: Imagine a world where there are no apps on L1.  Every app is on L2 and all users are on one or more L2s.

author: sky.cactus
content: You pick the L2 you spend most of your time interacting with (maybe a payment network, maybe a gambling site, maybe a game, maybe a trading site, whatever) and you park your funds there most of the time.

author: sky.cactus
content: You only move through layer 1 when you want to get to another L2.

author: treyzania
content: ^ most economic activity in general should be confined within rollups

author: hikariws
content:
Then that's no roolups, they're different networks.

The idea of L2 is to rely on L1, not be independent, because then it's not L2. The idea of rollup isn't to be permanent storage, because then it's not rollup.

If "most economy activity" is on rollup and never go to L1, then it's better they become independent networks and not rollups.

author: hikariws
content: If I'm sending money to ETH and wanna buy DAI and lend it, it's worse if I send it to a L2 and lend, to later have to withdraw it from the L2. And during the years it's on L2 I'm exposed to extra risk. It's better to just lend it on L1 in a unique transactions instead of spending 2 and never have to worry with risks of a centralized L2.

author: treyzania
content: that's not how that works

author: treyzania
content: L2s inherit the security of the L1

author: hikariws
content: when it commits the data, or proof of the data, to L1

author: treyzania
content: it doesn't have to

author: treyzania
content: it depends on the security model

author: hikariws
content: yeah there are multiple types and implementations

author: treyzania
content: why would it be "better" to be independent networks?

author: hikariws
content: if data is stored only on L2 and never commited to L1, then why should the instance be L2 of another blockchain?

author: treyzania
content: can you rephrase that?

author: hikariws
content: IDK how to explain better. There are multiple kinds and implementations of L2. L2 principle is to be faster and/or cheaper than L1 and to achieve that it's less decentralized, less secure, etc. L2 relies on L1. If a runtime engine doesn't need an L1 and has no benefit from it then there's no need to use it.

author: hikariws
content: If we're in a situation that multiple L2 instances are storing their data on their own and data is never commited to L1, then L1 is useless, they'd be implemented as independent networks and not as L2. They can exchange data with atomic swap, bridge, centralized exchange, etc instead of some L1 that's barely used.

author: treyzania
content:
> If we're in a situation that multiple L2 instances are storing their data on their own and data is never commited to L1, then L1 is useless, 
this is not true, the L1 is the fallback in the event of failure

author: treyzania
content: off-chain data availability networks are not entirely independent networks, they're complementary mechanisms

author: hikariws
content: could u explain how that fallback works?

author: treyzania
content: let's take a rollup as an example

author: treyzania
content: the contract just verifies the snark for the state transition

author: treyzania
content: normal exits are initiated from within the rollup itself

author: treyzania
content: but it's possible (in a well-designed rollup, at least) for users to be able to provide proofs for their funds within the rollup's state and withdraw their funds to addresses on L1 directly

author: treyzania
content: with state channels, if a counterparty disappears then the most recent state can just be posted to chain and played out that way

author: treyzania
content: when L2s are designed the idea is that in the happy case all or most of the interactivity can happen off-chain, because in the happy case we can trust each other not to misbehave

author: treyzania
content: in the event someone does misbehave, the contracts on L1 are there in order to enforce the rules of the contract, so we're able to trust each other not to misbehave (again, within the security assumptions) because we know the contracts anchoring to the L1 exist in order to rectify the situation

author: treyzania
content: in an ideal world, relatively little *computational* activity should have to happen on the base ledger that everything in anchored to, at least in comparison to all of the economic activity happening off-chain

author: hikariws
content:
Ah I think I got it, so from L1 we can withdraw without relying on L2 approval.

But this creates some limitations, like we can't have NFTs on the L2, we can't have FTs on L2 that don't exist on L1. Some use cases work on this L2 model but not all use cases could be used on it.

author: treyzania
content:
> If a runtime engine doesn't need an L1 and has no benefit from it then there's no need to use it.
So I don't know what you mean by this, all L2s base their security in the ledger they're based on

author: treyzania
content: well part of this is because the ERC721 standard isn't quite flexible enough to support everything that would be necessary for that

author: treyzania
content: and there's nothing really stopping you from issuing tokens that exist only in a specific rollup, but it inherits the security properties of that rollup

author: hikariws
content: so we can't run all use cases on L2

author: treyzania
content: like what?

author: treyzania
content: there's nothing stopping someone from using some hacks to create an ERC20 on the L1 that's a wrapper around the issuer ERC20 contract existing only in a rollup, to be able to interact with it on other rollups or other L2s

author: hikariws
content: L2 can't be used to run everything and L1 be used only when we have some possible misbehave or when transfering funds from one instance to another. There are use cases that benefit more than others from L2.
